title: Marleen Molenaar
text:
Marleen Molenaar (born 30 September 1962) is a retired Dutch <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> and featured for the <a href="Netherlands%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands women's national football team</a>. She later oversaw <a href="Eredivisie%20%28women%29">Eredivisie</a> clubs <a href="AZ%20Alkmaar%20%28women%29">AZ Alkmaar</a> and <a href="AFC%20Ajax%20%28women%29">AFC Ajax</a>, and won the league four times between the two clubs.
Early life and education.
Molenaar, of <a href="Laren%2C%20North%20Holland">Laren</a>, <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, didn't start playing football until the age of 16 when in <a href="Education%20in%20the%20Netherlands%23Secondary%20education">secondary school</a>. Upon consultation with coaches from the Netherlands national team, she decided to play overseas to and continue her education, ultimately landing at the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Santa%20Barbara">University of California, Santa Barbara</a> in Spring 1984. While enrolled as a student, she played for the <a href="UC%20Santa%20Barbara%20Gauchos">UC Santa Barbara Gauchos</a> women's soccer team, where she played forward with future internationals <a href="Carin%20Jennings-Gabarra">Carin Jennings</a> and <a href="Gina%20Segadelli">Gina Cassella</a>. Molenaar broke the school's record for assists in a season with 17 total en route to the <a href="1984%20NCAA%20Women%27s%20Soccer%20Tournament">1984 NCAA Women's Soccer Tournament</a>, the first time the Gauchos had appeared in the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Women%27s%20Soccer%20Championship">NCAA Division I Women's Soccer Championship</a>. Upon completion of her freshman season, she appeared in 22 games for the Gauchos and scored 13 goals.
International career.
Molenaar made her national team debut for <a href="Netherlands%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> on 3 October 1989 in an international friendly against <a href="Belgium%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a>. She appeared in <a href="UEFA%20Women%27s%20Euro%201991%20qualifying">UEFA Women's Euro 1991 qualifying</a> matches shortly thereafter. She scored her only international goal on 28 May 1991 in a friendly against the <a href="United%20States%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">United States</a>. Her last international appearance came later that year in October 1991 against <a href="Sweden%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a>.
Post-playing career.
Molenaar was named manager of <a href="AZ%20Alkmaar%20%28women%29">AZ Alkmaar</a> prior to the start of the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Eredivisie%20%28women%29">2007–08 Eredivisie</a> season, the first for the league and club. Under her leadership, the club won the first three Eredivisie titles prior to leaving the club in July 2010.
<a href="AFC%20Ajax%20%28women%29">AFC Ajax</a> named Molenaar as their manager prior to their inaugural season in the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20BeNe%20League">2012–13 BeNe League</a>. She won the <a href="KNVB%20Women%27s%20Cup">KNVB Women's Cup</a> and another Eredivisie title before leaving the club in November 2017.
Personal life.
Molenaar's father, <a href="Cees%20Molenaar">Cees Molenaar</a>, was also a footballer who founded <a href="AZ%20Alkmaar">AZ Alkmaar</a> with her uncle, <a href="Klaas%20Molenaar">Klaas Molenaar</a>.
Honors.
AZ Alkmaar
AFC Ajax
